ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

We at City of Decatur (Lake Bridgeport) Raw Water Pump Station are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.  Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, we are completely coordinated with the Lake Bridgeport Fire Department who provides highly trained emergency response personnel to control and mitigate the effects of the release.

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The City of Decatur?s Lake Bridgeport Raw Water Pump Station is located alongside Lake Bridgeport in Bridgeport, Texas.  The facility's primary activity involves pumping lake water to the City of Decatur Water Treatment Plant.  

The only regulated substance present at our facility is chlorine.  Chlorine is used for primary treatment of the raw lake water prior to transfer to the treatment plant in Decatur.  The maximum capacity of chlorine at our facility is 4,000 pounds.  Gaseous chlorine is drawn from one of two ton-containers and mixed with a side stream of pumped lake water, and the side stream is then added to the primary water stream being pumped to the City of Decatur Water Treatment Plant.

The facility is classified under North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 22131, and is not subject to OSHA?s 29 CFR 1910.119, the Process Safety Management standard.  This set of conditions dictates Prevention Program Level 2 applicability under the RMP regulation. 

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements put forth by

standards; and

- In the unlikely event of their occurrence, all incidents, unsafe conditions, or other near-misses are promptly and thoroughly investigated by a qualified team to determine their cause and to implement corrective actions to ensure that the condition will not reoccur.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The chlorine system is designed to meet current design standards for chlorine storage and handling systems.  A Hazard Review was conducted to verify design and operational safety, and to identify the potential for safety enhancements.  The analysis included the delivery and connection of chlorine containers, as well as the storage and injection systems and operating practices.

The chlorine system is subjected to regular inspection and maintenance to ensure its ongoing integrity.  As part of regular duties of the operations staff, the chlorine vessels and injection equipment, piping, and injection system are visually inspected to ensure that no undue hazards are present.  The chlorine containers are periodically subjected to testing by the chlorine supplier to verify their integrity.

Protection of the chlorine storage system includes a completely fenced operating area with a controlled access gate to the entrance to the facility.  Only site employees are allowed access to the area.  The delivery of chlorine containers is strictly managed and controlled.  Container delivery vehicles are secured, and trained delivery staff use container-specific equipment to place the containers into position.  The delivery operation is constantly manned by a trained individual who can immediately respond to any abnormal conditions that may occur during delivery or connection to the injection system.

Chlorine injection systems utilize industry-specific equipment with built in release mitigation features.  At the point of mixing with the water side stream, a vacuum is created to draw chlorine gas from the cylinder.  In the event of a chlorine injection line or connect

ion break, the equipment automatically and immediately detects the loss of vacuum and shuts down the flow of chlorine from the cylinder.  With this feature, the amount of chlorine released to the atmosphere is limited to the small amount contained in the injection tubing at the time of the failure.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The City of Decatur Raw Water Pump Station has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringent release prevention policies, there have been no accidental releases during this period.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The City of Decatur Raw Water Pump Station features a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within our processes that would require a modified emergency response.

The site emergency plan is coordinated with and verified by the Wise County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A review and revalidation of the original Hazard Review identified the opportunity for more thorough and more frequent equipment inspections and maintenance of the chlorine storage area.
